metadata.title: Strength properties of nano-MgO and cement stabilized coastal silty clay subjected to sulfuric acid attack

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 25 May 2019 Accepted 1 August 2019
KEYWORDS Nano-MgO; cement; silty clay; sulfuric acid attack; direct shear test

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The stabilization of soils by mixing them with cementitious binders has been widely used in many infrastructure projects, such as strength improvement for the subbases of pavements, ground improvement for foundation soils and land reclamation for dredged infills (e.g., Subramaniam and Banerjee 2014; Subramaniam, Sreenadh, and Banerjee 2016; Kang, Tsuchida, and Kim 2017; Pan et al. 2018, 2019; Jiang et al. 2018; Jiang, Du, and Liu 2018; Xiao, Wang, and Goh 2017; Xiao et al. 2018; Yao et al. 2018; Zhang et al. 2018; Wu et al. 2019). However, cement production entails severe environmental concerns. Barcelo et al. (2014) reported that cement production contributes 5-7% to carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions all over the world, which causes severe environmental problems such as global warming. In order to reduce CO2 emission during cement manufacture, additive materials that can increase the performance of cemented soil are highly desirable to reduce the use of cement (e.g., Du and Pang 2018a; Gupta, Kua, and Koh 2018; Zhu et al. 2018; Wei and Cen 2019). Recently, nanotechnology-based materials have attracted increasing attention in the field of civil engineering (e.g., Du, Du, and Liu 2015; Park et al. 2015; Razi, Abdul Razak, and Khalid 2016; Ghasabkolaei et al. 2017; Du and Pang 2018b). For example, the use of nanosilica in cemented soil has been extensively investigated (e.g., Choobbasti, Vafaei, and Kutanaei 2015; Kutanaei and Choobbasti 2016, 2017; Choobbasti and Kutanaei 2017; Choobbasti, Vafaei, and Kutanaei 2018). Nowadays, Ye, Yu, and Zhang (2015), Polat, Demirbo ga, and Karag€ol (2017) and Song et al. (2018) reported that the use of nano-MgO was effective in improving the mechanical performance of cement-based materials. However, the number of studies related to the use of nano-MgO in cement-soil stabilization remains insufficient (see Wang et al. 2018; Yao et al. 2019a, forthcoming). In the present study, nanoMgO was adopted as an additive for the cement and the efficiency of nano-MgO cement-admixed clay was assessed from a few sets of direct shear tests. In many applications, infrastructures are often subjected to severe service environments (e.g., Song et al. 2019). Furthermore, exposure to products such as sulfuric acid poses extreme challenges to the infrastructure materials (e.g., Yao et al. 2019a). Therefore, in addition to the mechanical enhancement of nano-MgO, it is of great importance to investigate the performance of the stabilized soil under harsh service environments (e.g., Puppala et al. 2004; Yu et al. 2016). Thus, the response of the nano-MgO cement-stabilized soil to exposure in various sulfuric acid concentrations for different durations was undertaken in controlled laboratory conditions to simulate behavior in aggressive service environments. The impact of the sulfuric acid attack on the shear strength of the stabilized clay also was explored using direct shear tests.
CONTACT Kai Yao yaokai@u.nus.edu Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, National University of Singapore, 1 Engineering Drive 2, Singapore 117576, Singapore 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group
Figure 1. XRD diffractograms of silty clay.
Table 1. Physical parameters of sulfuric acid.
Composition Molar weight Density (g/cm3) Melting point ( C) Boiling point ( C) Concentration (%) Heat capacity J/(g K) H2SO4 98.078 1.8305 10.371 337 0.002 1.416

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Soil used in the present investigation was collected from the coastal areas of Zhejiang Province, P.R. China, and was sieved in the laboratory through 2mm mesh sieve to remove the coarse particles. The specific gravity, liquid limit and plastic limit of the soil were 2.6, 43.5% and 30%, respectively (Wang et al. 2018; Yao et al. 2019a, forthcoming). An X-ray diffraction (XRD) scan of the silty clay is shown in Figure 1.
Type 1 OPC and nano-MgO were used to stabilize the silty clay. Nano-MgO had a density of 3.58 g/cm3 and a particle size range between 15 and 20nm. Sulfuric acid was used to simulate a harsh environment. The physical parameters of sulfuric acid are summarized in Table 1 (Yao et al. 2019a).

sections.heading: 2.2. Specimen preparation and testing
sections.text:
The mix ratio followed in the present study was based on the definition proposed by Xiao, Lee, and Chin (2014) and Yao
Figure 3. Shear stress displacement curves for mixture with various nano-MgO contents: (a) nano-MgO content ¼ 0; (b) nano-MgO content ¼ 5&; (c) nano-MgO content ¼ 10&; (d) nano-MgO content ¼ 15&; (e) nano-MgO content ¼ 20&.
et al. (2019b, forthcoming). The mix ratio of cement-admixed clay is defined as the mass ratio of soil solids (s): dry cement solids (c): water (w). Cement content (Aw) is the mass ratio of cement to dry soil solid (i.e., mc/ms), while total water content (Cw) is the mass ratio of water to the sum of dry soil and cement solids (i.e.,mw=ðms þmcÞ). The mix design used in this study was s:c:w¼ 12:2.9:4.47 (i.e., 24% cement content and 30% total water content). The nano-MgO content (an) is the mass of nano-MgO to the total mass of the cement-clay mixture (i.e.,mn=ðms þmc þmwÞ) (Yao et al., forthcoming). The raw materials were weighed according to the mix design and were mixed in a Hobart mixer using a spatula. The deionized water was added to the dry mixture and mixed homogeneously in the mechanical mixer for 10minutes. The nano-MgOcement-clay mixture then was poured into cylindrical molds that were 61.8mm in diameter and 20mm in height and compacted in three layers. Thereafter, the specimens were soaked in a deionized water for the first 24hours and then were demolded to settle in an incubator with temperature of 22 C and humidity of 95% (Yao et al., forthcoming), as shown in Figure 2(a). To simulate the extreme service environment condition, specimens were soaked in sulfuric acid solution for a
required exposure period (Figure 2(b)) and direct shear tests (ASTM 1994) were performed (Figure 2(c)). Vertical normal stresses from 100 to 400 kPa were applied on the specimens, which were sheared at a rate of 0.02mm/min (Yao et al., forthcoming). Table 2 summarizes the experiment test program followed in this study.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of nano-MgO content
sections.text:
The shear stress displacement curves obtained from the direct shear tests for the cement-admixed clay with various nano-MgO contents are shown in Figure 3. With an increase in shear displacement, the shear stress increases steadily until it reaches the maximum capacity, beyond which there is a sudden drop. The shear strength corresponds to the first peak shear stress for each case. It can also be identified that for specimens with the same nano-MgO content, the shear strength increases with increase in the applied normal stress. The variation in shear strength with nano-MgO content is shown in Figure 4. It can be observed from Figure 4(a) that the maximum shear strength was obtained for the cementadmixed clay with 5& nano-MgO content. Once the
Figure 4. Effect of nano-MgO content on shear strength of stabilized soil: (a) Shear strength; (b) Normalized shear strength.
nano-MgO content exceeded this optimal value, the shear strength began to decrease. This is because the overuse of nano-MgO can generate micro-cracks inside the specimen, leading to poor durability performance of the mixture. It is understood from the normalized shear strength (Figure 4(b)) that the strength increment ratio under optimal nano-MgO content was between 1.3 and 1.5 under an applied normal stress of 100 to 400kPa. It was noted also that the cementadmixed clay with a nano-MgO content of 20& still showed an increase in shear strength compared to those with no nanoMgO addition. This means the use of nano-MgO within the adopted content (5–20&) was beneficial against sulfuric acid attack. In order to compare the shear strength components, the relationship between shear strength and normal stress was investigated (Craig 1983; Yao et al., forthcoming):
s ¼ cþ r tanu (1) where s is the shear strength, r is the normal stress, c denotes cohesion and u refers to friction angle. The value
of c and u shown in Figure 5 was back-calculated from the test results summarized in Figure 4. Figure 5(a) illustrates that the cohesion of the mixture was most mobilized at the optimal nano-MgO content. In contrast, the friction angle did not show any apparent variation with different nano-MgO contents (see Figure 5(b)). This implies that the function of the nano-MgO in the mixture was mainly to increase cohesion between the soil/cement particle mixture.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of sulfuric acid concentration
sections.text:
The specimens were soaked in sulfuric acid solution (concentration ¼ 0.03mol/L, 0.06 mol/L, 0.09mol/L and 0.12mol/L, respectively) for 14 days after curing. Specimens soaked in distilled water were taken as a reference for control purposes (see Figure 6(a)). Visual observation confirmed that the surfaces of specimens that had been soaked in the sulfuric acid solutions were very
Figure 6. Specimen appearance after erosion by solution with various sulfuric acid concentrations (a) 0mol/L (pure water); (b) 0.03mol/L; (c) 0.06mol/L; (d) 0.09mol/L; (e) 0.12mol/L.
rough, due to attack by the sulfuric acid, see Figure 6. It was noted also that the surface damage on the specimen became more severe with an increase in the sulfuric acid concentration. Shear stress displacement curves for specimens that had been soaked in the sulfuric acid solutions at various sulfuric acid concentrations are shown in Figure 7. Figure 8(a) shows that the shear strength of the mixture decreased with increasing sulfuric acid solution concentration. From the normalized shear strengths shown in Figure 8(b), it is evident that the strength ratio increase over that of the control group was only 0.77 for most cases (normal stress ¼ 100, 200 and 300 kPa). In order to understand the influence of sulfuric acid concentration on the shear strength components, c and u were calculated separately. The variation of shear strength components (i.e., cohesion and friction angle) of nano-MgO cement-admixed clay soaked in different sulfuric acid solution concentration is shown in Figure 9. It can be
Figure 7. Shear stress displacement curves for mixture after erosion by sulfuric acid solution with various sulfuric acid concentration (a) 0mol/L (pure water); (b) 0.03mol/L; (c) 0.06mol/L; (d) 0.09mol/L; (e) 0.12mol/L.
found in Figure 9(a) that cohesion of the nano-MgO cement-admixed clay decreased up to the sulfuric acid concentration of 0.06mol/L. However, the cohesion showed a slight incremental increase between 0.06 and 0.12mol/L sulfuric acid concentration. In contrast, the friction angle (Figure 9(b)) decreased continuously with increasing sulfuric acid concentration.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of sulfuric acid exposure period
sections.text:
After curing, samples of cement-admixed clay with nanoMgO content of 10& were submerged inside 0.06mol/L sulfuric acid solution, for 7, 14, 21, 28 days, respectively, to investigate the effect of the sulfuric acid exposure period. The relevant shear stress displacement curves are shown in Figure 10. It can be deduced from Figure 11(a) that the shear strength of the nano-MgO cement-admixed clay increased continuously during the soaking period even with the sulfuric acid environment. This may be attributable to the continuous hydration and pozzolanic reaction of the cementitious materials. During the first 14 days of immersion in the sulfuric acid solution, the shear strength of the
mixture showed a significant increase. However, for longer soaking periods, such as 21 days, the strength did not change a great deal more. This may due to near-completion of the cementation in the earlier soaking period, while the negative effects of sulfuric erosion tend to be more obvious. For some normal stresses, such as 100 and 400 kPa, the shear strength showed a slight decrease after soaking in sulfuric acid solution for 28 days. This reflected the influence of sulfuric acid attack, which could have a significant long-term deleterious effect. Similar trends were observed for the normalized shear strength curves, as shown in Figure 11(b). In terms of the shear strength parameters, Figure 12 indicates that both the cohesion value and the friction angle of the mixture increased up to an exposure period of 21 days, beyond which a slight decrease was observed.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The influence of nano-MgO as an additive in enhancing the strength properties of cement-admixed clay was investigated using a few sets of direct shear tests, considering the effect of sulfuric acid attack. Based on the observations from experimental tests, it was concluded that the optimal nanoMgO content was 5& for cemented clay with the specific mix ratio in this study (cement content ¼ 24%; total water
Figure 9. Effect of sulfuric acid concentration on shear strength parameters of stabilized soil: (a) Cohesion c; (b) Friction angle u.
content ¼ 30%). It was observed that the cohesion of the mixture was most mobilized under the optimal nano-MgO content of 5&. When exposed to the sulfuric acid environment, the shear strength of the mixture decreased with increasing the sulfuric acid concentration. And both cohesion and friction angle tend to decrease with increasing sulfuric acid concentration. However, the shear strength of the mixture increased during the soaking period even in the sulfuric acid solution. Within the first 14 days of immersion in sulfuric acid solution, the shear strength of mixture showed a significant increase. However, for a longer soaking period, such as 21 days, the strength does not change a great deal more. Note that the above conclusions are only drawn based on the results of direct shear test carried out in this study. More meaningful findings may be found by conducting other types of test such as unconfined compressive
Figure 10. Shear stress displacement curves for mixture after erosion by solution under various erosion periods: (a) 7 days; (b) 14 days; (c) 21 days; (d) 28 days.
Figure 11. Effect of sulfuric acid erosion period on shear strength of stabilized soil: (a) Shear strength; (b) Normalized shear strength.
strength test, and it is also helpful to achieve a more solid conclusion (e.g., Yao et al. 2019a).
Funding
This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (41772311), Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (LY17E080016), and Open Research Fund of State Key Laboratory of Geomechanics and Geotechnical Engineering, Institute of Rock and Soil Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Science (Z017013).

referenceMentions.context: The stabilization of soils by mixing them with cementitious binders has been widely used in many infrastructure projects, such as strength improvement for the subbases of pavements, ground improvement for foundation soils and land reclamation for dredged infills (e.g., Subramaniam and Banerjee 2014; Subramaniam, Sreenadh, and Banerjee 2016; Kang, Tsuchida, and Kim 2017; Pan et al. 2018, 2019; Jiang et al. 2018; Jiang, Du, and Liu 2018; Xiao, Wang, and Goh 2017; Xiao et al. 2018; Yao et al. 2018; Zhang et al. 2018; Wu et al. 2019).

The stabilization of soils by mixing them with cementitious binders has been widely used in many infrastructure projects, such as strength improvement for the subbases of pavements, ground improvement for foundation soils and land reclamation for dredged infills (e.g., Subramaniam and Banerjee 2014; Subramaniam, Sreenadh, and Banerjee 2016; Kang, Tsuchida, and Kim 2017; Pan et al. 2018, 2019; Jiang et al. 2018; Jiang, Du, and Liu 2018; Xiao, Wang, and Goh 2017; Xiao et al. 2018; Yao et al. 2018; Zhang et al. 2018; Wu et al. 2019).

The stabilization of soils by mixing them with cementitious binders has been widely used in many infrastructure projects, such as strength improvement for the subbases of pavements, ground improvement for foundation soils and land reclamation for dredged infills (e.g., Subramaniam and Banerjee 2014; Subramaniam, Sreenadh, and Banerjee 2016; Kang, Tsuchida, and Kim 2017; Pan et al. 2018, 2019; Jiang et al. 2018; Jiang, Du, and Liu 2018; Xiao, Wang, and Goh 2017; Xiao et al. 2018; Yao et al. 2018; Zhang et al. 2018; Wu et al. 2019).

In order to reduce CO2 emission during cement manufacture, additive materials that can increase the performance of cemented soil are highly desirable to reduce the use of cement (e.g., Du and Pang 2018a; Gupta, Kua, and Koh 2018; Zhu et al. 2018; Wei and Cen 2019).

Recently, nanotechnology-based materials have attracted increasing attention in the field of civil engineering (e.g., Du, Du, and Liu 2015; Park et al. 2015; Razi, Abdul Razak, and Khalid 2016; Ghasabkolaei et al. 2017; Du and Pang 2018b).

Recently, nanotechnology-based materials have attracted increasing attention in the field of civil engineering (e.g., Du, Du, and Liu 2015; Park et al. 2015; Razi, Abdul Razak, and Khalid 2016; Ghasabkolaei et al. 2017; Du and Pang 2018b).

Therefore, in addition to the mechanical enhancement of nano-MgO, it is of great importance to investigate the performance of the stabilized soil under harsh service environments (e.g., Puppala et al. 2004; Yu et al. 2016).
The physical parameters of sulfuric acid are summarized in Table 1 (Yao et al. 2019a).

metadata.abstractText: The characteristics of nanometer magnesium oxide (nano-MgO) admixed cement in the treatment of clay were studied in direct shear tests. The chemical resistance of the admixed clay cement was investigated by soaking specimens in sulfuric acid solution. Various contents of nano-MgO (from 5‰ to 20‰) were mixed with ordinary Portland cement (OPC) and its effect on the shear strength of cemented silty clay was studied. The test results showed that the optimal nano-MgO content to achieve highest shear strength was 5‰. It was observed also that the cohesion was most mobilized at the optimal nano-MgO content. Visual observation of the soak-tested samples revealed that damage to the surface of the specimens became more severe at higher sulfuric acid concentrations. In general, the shear strength of the mixture decreased with an increase in sulfuric acid concentration. Moreover, with an increase in sulfuric acid concentration (0.03 to 0.06mol/L), both the cohesion and the friction angle decreased. However, the shear strength of the mixture increased with an increase in the soaking period, even in the sulfuric acid environment. Within the first 14days of the soaking period, the shear strength of the mixture showed a clear change. However, for longer soaking periods (i.e., 21days), the strength did not change a great deal more. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 25 May 2019 Accepted 1 August 2019
